<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_initial_state_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_set_initial_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  size_t read_buf_size;

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert ( (0 == (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_INIT == c->tls_state) );
  mhd_assert ( (0 != (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_NO_TLS == c->tls_state) );
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT == c->state);

  c->keepalive = MHD_CONN_KEEPALIVE_UNKOWN;
  c->event_loop_info = MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_READ;

  memset (&c->rq, 0, sizeof(c->rq));
  memset (&c->rp, 0, sizeof(c->rp));

  c->write_buffer = NULL;
  c->write_buffer_size = 0;
  c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
  c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;

  c->continue_message_write_offset = 0;

  c->read_buffer_offset = 0;
  read_buf_size = c->daemon->pool_size / 2;
  c->read_buffer
    = MHD_pool_allocate (c->pool,
                         read_buf_size,
                         false);
  c->read_buffer_size = read_buf_size;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: The listed fragments are the occurrences of pointer declarations or pointer-valued members/uses in this function and therefore are the places to inspect for compliance with Rule 8.13 (i.e. whether pointers could/should be to const-qualified types). Other lines in the function are simple scalar initializations or enum/state assignments (e.g. keepalive, event_loop_info, various size/offset integer assignments, read_buf_size calculation, c->state assertion) that do not involve pointer types and thus are not relevant to the requirement that pointers should point to const-qualified types whenever possible.
